paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the rocky, likely tidally locked exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere, as inferred from JWST MIRI thermal phase-curve spectroscopy and the 15 µm CO2 band?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: JWST/MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One planet (TRAPPIST-1 b) observed over an orbital phase curve with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Low-resolution JWST MIRI spectroscopy spanning an orbital phase curve, measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure near the ~15 µm CO2 band to constrain day–night heat transport and possible atmospheric absorption.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Atmosphere-free vs atmosphere-bearing retrieval scenarios
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Multiple model families (bare-rock/no-atmosphere, CO2-rich atmosphere, O2-rich atmosphere) fit to the same phase-curve dataset
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A retrieval workflow compares a null bare-rock, minimal-redistribution model against atmosphere-bearing cases (including CO2-rich and O2-rich compositions) to determine which scenarios best explain the combined phase-curve amplitude/offsets and spectral behavior.

major_limitations: Single-planet study; does not establish how common atmospheres are among M-dwarf rocky planets.
Quantitative posteriors depend on retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, clouds/hazes).
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
